liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ron DeSantis, the man considered to be Donald Trump's leading rival for the 2024 Republican nomination, has taken to social media to share his thoughts on this morning's developments. He says while he hasn't read the indictment, he believes "we need to enact reforms so that Americans have the right to remove cases from Washington, DC to their home districts". "Washington, DC is a 'swamp' and it is unfair to have to stand trial before a jury that is reflective of the swamp mentality," DeSantis wrote. "One of the reasons our country is in decline is the politicization of the rule of law. No more excuses—I will end the weaponization of the federal government."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Republican rival Ron DeSantis responds to indictment of Donald Trump

children.content: Ron DeSantis, the man considered to be Donald Trump's leading rival for the 2024 Republican nomination, has taken to social media to share his thoughts on this morning's developments.
He says while he hasn't read the indictment, he believes "we need to enact reforms so that Americans have the right to remove cases from Washington, DC to their home districts".
"Washington, DC is a 'swamp' and it is unfair to have to stand trial before a jury that is reflective of the swamp mentality," DeSantis wrote.
"One of the reasons our country is in decline is the politicization of the rule of law. No more excuses—I will end the weaponization of the federal government."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: According to prosecutors, Mr Trump was advised by several senior officials and advisers that claims he had made about electoral irregularities were false. They include then vice president Mike Pence, White House lawyers, and the Director of National Intelligence. In the weeks leading up to the election, Mr Trump is alleged to have falsely told Mr Pence at least three times he had the authority to reject the electoral results, even though Mr Pence pushed back every time. One of the conversations took place after Mr Pence called Mr Trump on Christmas to wish him a merry Christmas, prosecutors said. After Mr Pence pushed back on the plan in a call a week later, Mr Trump told him, "You're too honest," prosecutors said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Donald Trump was aware claims of voting fraud were false, indictment says

prosecutors said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US singer Lizzo (real name Melissa Viviane Jefferson) is being sued by three former dancers who accuse the Grammy winner of sexual harassment. They also allege the singer and her production company created a hostile work environment. The civil lawsuit filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court claims Lizzo pressured the dancers to engage with nude performers at a club in Amsterdam and shamed one of them for her weight gain before firing her. Plaintiffs Arianna Davis, Crystal Williams and Noelle Rodriguez make numerous charges including sexual, religious and racial harassment, disability discrimination, assault and false imprisonment. The legal complaint seeks unspecified damages and names Lizzo, her production company Big Grrrl Big Touring, and Shirlene Quigley, captain of the performer's dance team. Lizzo is yet to publicly respond to the lawsuit.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lizzo is being sued by ex-dancers over alleged sexual harassment and a hostile work environment

props.alt: A black woman on stage holding a microphone and pointing. Other dancers behind her

children.content: (AP: Rob Grabowski/Invision)
US singer Lizzo (real name Melissa Viviane Jefferson) is being
sued by three former dancers who accuse the Grammy winner of sexual harassment
. They also allege the singer and her production company created a hostile work environment.

The civil lawsuit filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court claims Lizzo pressured the dancers to engage with nude performers at a club in Amsterdam and shamed one of them for her weight gain before firing her.
Plaintiffs Arianna Davis, Crystal Williams and Noelle Rodriguez make
numerous charges including sexual, religious and racial harassment, disability discrimination, assault and false imprisonment
The legal complaint seeks unspecified damages and names Lizzo, her production company Big Grrrl Big Touring, and Shirlene Quigley, captain of the performer's dance team.
Lizzo is yet to publicly respond to the lawsuit.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says he has spoken with Greens leader Adam Bandt about the housing fund which is being reintroduced to parliament today. He says the Greens have written that they like the housing fund being unresolved as they want to campaign over the issue. "It's a bizarre position which says you want people to be kept in poverty so that you can have a political campaign," Albanese tells ABC Radio. Albanese says the government can't dismantle federation to pass the legislation and the issue of rent freezes (which The Greens are calling for) is the jurisdiction of the states and territories. The housing fund would deliver 30,000 social and affordable homes in its first five years, with 4,000 for women and children at risk of domestic violence. Should the bill be blocked a second time, the issue could be used as a trigger for a double dissolution, in which all of the Senate seats are up for election. Greens senator Sarah Hanson-Young says the party will meet the government later this week for further negotiations on the housing bill. You can hear the PM's full interview below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM says The Greens have a 'bizarre' position on the government's housing bill

featuredLink.title: Anthony Albanese on Housing and the Voice - ABC Radio National

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says he has spoken with Greens leader Adam Bandt about the housing fund which is being reintroduced to parliament today.
He says the Greens have written that they like the housing fund being unresolved as they want to campaign over the issue.
"It's a bizarre position which says you want people to be kept in poverty so that you can have a political campaign," Albanese tells ABC Radio.
Albanese says the government can't dismantle federation to pass the legislation and the issue of rent freezes (which The Greens are calling for) is the jurisdiction of the states and territories.
The housing fund would deliver 30,000 social and affordable homes in its first five years
, with 4,000 for women and children at risk of domestic violence.
Should the bill be blocked a second time, the issue could be used as a trigger for a double dissolution, in which all of the Senate seats are up for election.
Greens senator Sarah Hanson-Young says the party will meet the government later this week for further negotiations on the housing bill.
You can hear the PM's full interview below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The policy will be reintroduced today, but a vote won't take place until October. The Greens and the Coalition are opposed to the $10 billion Housing Australia Future fund, as it stands. The government has made some concessions, but the Greens want further changes, including freezing rent increases for two years. Shadow Housing Minister Michael Sukkar says the Coalition will continue to oppose it. "We have a mandate to support policies that we think are in the best interests of our country, we have a duty to ensure we don't support things that are wholly inadequate," he says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The government's $10b housing bill will be reintroduced to parliament today

children.content: (ABC News: John Gunn)
The policy will be reintroduced today, but a vote won't take place until October.
The Greens and the Coalition are opposed to the $10 billion Housing Australia Future fund
, as it stands.
The government has made some concessions, but the Greens want further changes, including freezing rent increases for two years.
Shadow Housing Minister Michael Sukkar says the Coalition will continue to oppose it.
"We have a mandate to support policies that we think are in the best interests of our country, we have a duty to ensure we don't support things that are wholly inadequate," he says.

mediaThumbnail.caption: Shadow Housing Minister Michael Sukkar has disagreed with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's assertion that Labor has a mandate to pass the bill through Parliament

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After the Reserve Bank kept official interest rates on hold yesterday at 4.1 per cent, more economists think this may be the end of the RBA's rate-hiking cycle. RBA governor Philip Lowe noted that higher interest rates were bringing down inflation, but did not rule out raising borrowing costs again with annual inflation running at 6 per cent. Barrenjoey chief economist Jo Masters has lowered her forecasts for where official rates will peak, from 4.6 per cent to 4.1 per cent. She says it is likely the RBA board thinks there have been enough interest rate rises to lower inflation to between 2 to 3 per cent by mid-2025. "We read today’s statement as a signal that the board believes there is sufficient  tightening in the pipeline to achieve their inflation objective; that they want to be done  with the tightening cycle. "This sets a high bar to further rate hikes, and the onus on  the data to surprise sufficiently to force the board’s hand back to the table." UBS chief economist George Tharenou has lowered his forecast for the terminal rate from 4.35 per cent to 4.1 per cent, although a 0.25 per cent rise in November is possible, before a cut mid next year. The Commonwealth Bank now also expects the cash rate to remain on hold at 4.1 per cent for an extended period. National Australia Bank expects the peak cash rate to reach 4.35 per cent in November. Interest rate rises are slowing the economy with weaker inflation and retail sales. The recovery in home prices is also easing. Here's more from Stephanie Chalmers on The Business.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will the RBA stop raising rates now?

featuredLink.title: How interest rates are impacting house prices

children.content: After the Reserve Bank kept official interest rates on hold yesterday at 4.1 per cent, more economists think this may be the end of the RBA's rate-hiking cycle.
RBA governor Philip Lowe noted that higher interest rates were bringing down inflation, but did not rule out raising borrowing costs again with annual inflation running at 6 per cent.
Barrenjoey chief economist Jo Masters
has lowered her forecasts for where official rates will peak, from 4.6 per cent to 4.1 per cent.
She says it is likely the RBA board thinks there have been enough interest rate rises to lower inflation to between 2 to 3 per cent by mid-2025.

"We read today’s statement as a signal that the board believes there is sufficient  tightening in the pipeline to achieve their inflation objective; that they want to be done  with the tightening cycle.
"This sets a high bar to further rate hikes, and the onus on  the data to surprise sufficiently to force the board’s hand back to the table."
UBS chief economist George Tharenou
has lowered his forecast for the terminal rate from 4.35 per cent to 4.1 per cent, although a 0.25 per cent rise in November is possible, before a cut mid next year.
The Commonwealth Bank now also expects the cash rate to remain on hold at 4.1 per cent for an extended period.
National Australia Bank expects the peak cash rate to reach 4.35 per cent in November.
Interest rate rises are slowing the economy with weaker inflation and retail sales.
The recovery in home prices is also easing.
Here's more from Stephanie Chalmers on The Business.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Global credit ratings agency Fitch Ratings has cut the US credit rating from AAA to AA+. Fitch says the downgrade reflects the expected fiscal deterioration over the next three years, a high and growing general government debt burden, and the erosion of governance. In May, Fitch threatened to cut the AAA credit rating because of the US debt ceiling standoff. "In Fitch's view, there has been steady deterioration in standards of governance over the last 20 years, including on fiscal and debt matters, notwithstanding the June bipartisan agreement to suspend the debt limit until January 2025." "The repeated debt limit political standoffs and last minute resolutions have eroded confidence in fiscal management." Fitch is also predicting a mild recession for the US economy later this year and early next year because of high interest rates, weakening business investment and a slowdown in spending. It expects the Federal Reserve to lift interest rates one more time to 5.5 per cent to 5.75 per cent by next month. Standard and Poor's downgraded the US credit rating from the top AAA rating in 2011 after the US managed to avoid a debt default. Moody's Investors Service has maintained the US credit rating at AAA. Credit ratings are used by investors to assess a country or company's ability to repay their debts. The reality is a AA+ credit rating is still very high and won't have much impact on the borrowing costs of the US. But not every one agrees with Fitch's decision including former Treasury secretary Larry Summers.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US loses AAA credit rating

children.content: Global credit ratings agency Fitch Ratings has cut the US credit rating from AAA to AA+.
Fitch says the downgrade reflects the expected fiscal deterioration over the next three years, a high and growing general government debt burden, and the erosion of governance.
In May, Fitch threatened to cut the AAA credit rating because of the US debt ceiling standoff.

"In Fitch's view, there has been steady deterioration in standards of governance over the last 20 years, including on fiscal and debt matters, notwithstanding the June bipartisan agreement to suspend the debt limit until January 2025."
"The repeated debt limit political standoffs and last minute resolutions have eroded confidence in fiscal management."
Fitch is also predicting a mild recession for the US economy later this year and early next year because of high interest rates, weakening business investment and a slowdown in spending.
It expects the Federal Reserve to lift interest rates one more time to 5.5 per cent to 5.75 per cent by next month.
Standard and Poor's downgraded the US credit rating from the top AAA rating in 2011 after the US managed to avoid a debt default.
Moody's Investors Service has maintained the US credit rating at AAA.
Credit ratings are used by investors to assess a country or company's ability to repay their debts.
The reality is a AA+ credit rating is still very high and won't have much impact on the borrowing costs of the US.
But not every one agrees with Fitch's decision including former Treasury secretary Larry Summers.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Rio Tinto's boss says he's confident that China will roll out major stimulus to boost its flagging economy. China's economy is slowing down and Beijing has announced small measures to boost growth, although there's been no sign yet of the big cash splashes of the past. But Rio chief executive Jakob Stausholm has told Kirsten Aiken on The Business that he is "cautiously optimistic" about China. "I'm very encouraged by hearing that the government in China acknowledge that there are opportunities to strengthen the economy. "And experience tells us that when they acknowledge that there is an issue, that they know exactly how to address the issue." China announced support measures yesterday and the People's Bank of China says banks will be guided to reduce mortgage rates, however, there are no big spending plans, leaving investors disappointed. Here's Kirsten Aiken's interview with Jakob Stausholm.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rio Tinto boss confident of China stimulus

featuredLink.title: Can China stave off a crisis? Rio boss hopes it can

children.content: Rio Tinto's boss says he's confident that China will roll out major stimulus to boost its flagging economy.
China's economy is slowing down and Beijing has announced small measures to boost growth, although there's been no sign yet of the big cash splashes of the past.
But Rio chief executive Jakob Stausholm has told Kirsten Aiken on The Business that he is "cautiously optimistic" about China.
"I'm very encouraged by hearing that the government in China acknowledge that there are opportunities to strengthen the economy.
"And experience tells us that when they acknowledge that there is an issue, that they know exactly how to address the issue."
China announced support measures yesterday and the People's Bank of China says banks will be guided to reduce mortgage rates, however, there are no big spending plans, leaving
investors disappointed.
Here's Kirsten Aiken's interview with Jakob Stausholm.
